RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Atlas Pipeline Mid-Continent Holdings LLC / Markwest Oklahoma Gas Company LLC    

Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant (Facility ID: 100000201578)



ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION AND RESPONSE POLICIES



Atlas Pipeline Mid-Continent Holdings LLC (Atlas) is the majority owner and operator of three adjacent natural gas processing plants, called the Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant, in Coal County, Oklahoma.  The facility is designed to process natural gas and recover liquid products from natural gas by physical separation and cryogenic means.  Both petroleum condensates and natural gas liquids are recovered from the inlet pipeline gas in this process for off-site sales.



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of our process.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the plant, and notify the necessary outside agencies. 



DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant is located approximately 3.5 miles southeast of Centrahoma, Oklahoma, on Highway 3 and operates the process to produce the following petroleum products:



1. Y grade mixture from natural gas

2. Condensate

3. Residue Gas



OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS RESULTS



Atlas treats the entire facility with three gas plants as one process.  Several vessels at each gas plant were evaluated for offsite consequence analyses.  There are two worst-case scenarios (WCS) associated with a release of flammable substances at the Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant.  The first

scenario involves a vapor cloud explosion involving 252,515 pounds (60,000 gallons) of a flammable mixture contained in one of four interconnected natural gas liquid storage tanks at Coalgate. The entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion and impacting an area with a 0.5 mile radius. The second scenario involves a vapor cloud explosion involving 281,976 pounds (67,000 gallons) of a flammable mixture contained in a natural gas liquid product surge tank at Stonewall.  The entire inventory is assumed to release and ignite, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion and impacting an area with a 0.5 mile radius. The first vessel is located east of the second vessel causing different public receptors to be impacted in each release scenario. 



Since the plant is located in a populated area, the WCS could affect offsite endpoints and nearby public receptors.  Atlas has numerous controls to prevent such a release and to manage consequences. Mitigation measures include an automated plant shutdown system that can divert all incoming gas to an emergency flare. 



The alternative release scenario (ARS) for the flammable substances at the Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant is assumed to be a vapor cloud explosion resulting from the release of 92,612 pounds of the flammable mixture from the Natural Gas Liquids Product Surge Tank at the Stonewall Plant. The release would occur from valve failure leaving a two inch diameter opening in the bottom of the tank. The ARS would impact a radius of 0.4 miles, which includes offsite endpoints and nearby public receptors. The release is expected to be isolated by plant personnel within 15 minutes.



GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant is covered by the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Program to aid in accident release prevention.



A. Employee Participation



Atlas encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety managemen

t and accident prevention as follows:



1. Updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information

2. Performing necessary calculations for PSM and RMP

3. Maintaining good engineering practices

4. Participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team



Employees have access to all information pertaining to the accident prevention program.



B. Process Safety Information



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the process.  These technical documents address the following:



1. Chemical properties and associated hazards

2. Necessary Block Flow Diagrams of the process

3. Maximum intended inventories

4. Upper and Lower limits of process fixed and rotating equipment

5. Equipment design basis and configuration information

6. Identification of all necessary regulatory equipment design documents

7. Sufficient information to assure good engineering practices



The location of the technical documents referenced above is listed in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM Program.



Chemical specific information, including hazard and emergency response/exposure considerations, is provided in material safety data sheet (MSDS).  For specific areas within the process, the plant has documented safety-related limits for specific parameters such as temperatures, level and composition in the operator's procedures manual.  The plant maintains the overall process within these limits by using controls and monitoring instruments, trained personnel and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems. 



The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of the equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressures, temperature and electrical ratings.  This information, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provides a ba

sis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed facility changes to safety features to ensure these are not compromised. 



C. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant has a comprehensive program to identify and control hazard associated with the RMP covered scenario.  This program systematically examines and explores for potential hazards, then establishes controls to put in place to manage the potential hazards.  The PHA is conducted using checklists with a team consisting of Atlas' employees who have operation, maintenance, engineering, and safety experience.  The team identifies, evaluates, and makes recommendations to management of the potential hazards identified.  The team's findings are forwarded to Atlas and Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Management for resolution.  The approved mitigation options in response to the PHA team's findings are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.



The facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the scenario is no longer operating.  The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.



D. Operating Procedures



Atlas maintains written Operating Procedures of the covered process that address primary operations mandated by OSHA, EPA, Good Engineering Practice and manufacturers.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current accurate by management.  The procedures are maintained current and accurate revising them as necessary by employee suggestion, compliance audit, PHA, Good Engineering practice, Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) and implemented through Management of Change.



Covered Process

Operating procedures are readily available to operators in the process unit and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job task and ensure the covered process is operating within its safe limits.



E.  Training



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for employees involved in operating the covered process.  New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn specific duties and tasks.  A performance review and written test or hands on observation specific to the plant operations is administered and must be successfully completed during this training period.  After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they are allowed to work independently.  In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained at an acceptable level.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years, or more frequently upon request.  The training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills



F. Contractors



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near covered process equipment, the facility has procedures in place to ensure that contractors:



1. Perform their work in a safe manner

2. Have the appropriate knowledge and skills

3. Are aware of the hazards in their workplace

4. Understand what they should do in the event of an emergency

5. Understand and follow site safety rules

6. Inform facility personnel of any hazard that they find during their work



This is accomplished by provi

ding contractors with:



1. A process overview

2. Information about safety and health hazards

3. Emergency response plan requirements

4. Safe work practices before beginning work



In addition, the Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant Management will evaluate the contractor safety program and performance during the selection of a contractor.  Facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance with regard to their safety obligations. 



G. Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)



Atlas conducts a PSSR for any new facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup before placing the equipment in service.  This review provides one additional check that construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready. A PSSR involved field verification of the construction serves as quality assurance verification that the accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.



H. Mechanical Integrity



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant has established practices and procedures for the safe operation of fixed, rotating and emergency shutdown equipment.  The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:



1. Conducting training

2. Developing written procedures

3. Performing inspections and tests

4. Correcting identified deficiencies

5. Applying quality assurance measures



In combination, these activities form a system to maintain the mechanical integrity of the process.



Maintenance personnel receive training on:



1. Overview of the process

2. Safety and Health hazards

3. Applicable maintenance procedures

4. Emergency response plan

5. Applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.



Written procedures provide that work is performed in a

consistent manner and serve as a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help verify that equipment functions as intended and that equipment is within acceptable limits.  If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate safety concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service.  A management of change team will review the use of equipment and determine what action is necessary.



An integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps to determine that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 



I. Safe Work Practices



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant has long-standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, Industrial Standards, and Good Engineering Practice in place to help provide employee, public and process safety.



J. Management of Change



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all Reported Covered Scenarios.  This system requires that changes to items such as equipment, chemicals, technology, and procedures be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to:



1. Determine that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards

2. Verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the proposed change



Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes.



K. Incident Investigation



Atlas promptly investigates incidents related to a covered scenario that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in a fire/explosion, property damage, environmental loss or personal injur

y.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective action to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent future occurrences and forwards these results to plant management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years. 



L. Compliance Audits



At least every 3 years a Compliance Audit addressing OSHA, EPA, RMP and Good Engineering Practices are conducted by employees and management of the Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant.  This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to plant management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are completed.  Final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.  



M. Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



The following is a description of existing features applicable to prevention of accidental release of regulated substances in this facility.



Universal Prevention Activities



Atlas' accident release prevention and response policies are applied to the RMP covered process.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failure and human errors.



N. Specialized Safety Features



Site specific detection and control equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the plant to:



1. Contain/control a release

2. Quickly detect a release, and

3. Reduce the consequences of an RMP-regulated substance release



The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:



O. Release Detection



1. Facility walk-through once per shift

2. Alarms to signal

process upsets



P. Release Containment/Control



1. Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases. 

2. Automated and manual valves to permit isolation of the process

3. Automated plant shutdown system to shut down all engines, plant utilities and automatically operate all automatic valves to their fail-safe position, diverting all incoming gas to the emergency flare.

4. Curbing or diking to contain liquids releases

5. Atmospheric relief devices



Q. Release Mitigation



1. Fire suppression and extinguishing system

2. Trained emergency response personnel

3. Personal protective equipment

4. Blast resistant building to help protect control systems and personnel



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant has an excellent record of accident prevention since start-up.  There have been no accidental release from covered processes that resulted in death, injury or significant property damage on site, or known off site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage during this period.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION



The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b). The plant maintains a written emergency response plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of Atlas staff, local emergency response agencies, and the public if a release occurs. However, facility personnel are not trained to be first responders to large fires and should a release occur from one of the vessels the facility would rely on the local fire department to respond.  



Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed when certain employees must remain to operate critical plant operations before the

y evacuate.  The Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, Police and Sheriff's Office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.



ORGANIZATIONAL CHART



The following provides a facility organizational chart with respect to RMP responsibilities.



NAME: Clint Duty

TITLE: Vice President, Technical Services

REPORTS TO: Eugene Dubay, CEO

RESPONSIBILITIES:  Oversight of RMP Implementation, release prevention, response recordkeeping, training, and inspections.



NAME: Frank Eberle

TITLE: Area Manager

REPORTS TO: Dwayne Burks, Vice President - Operations

RESPONSIBILITIES:  Assist the Primary Response Coordinator with the above listed responsibilities.



NAME/TITLE: Area Supervisors

REPORTS TO: Response Coordinators

RESPONSIBILITIES: Assist Coordinators with RMP implementation & report incidents



NAME/TITLE: Onsite Personnel

REPORTS TO: Area Supervisors & Response Coordinators

RESPONSIBILITIES: Good housekeeping, reporting maintenance issues & incidents



NAME/TITLE: Onsite Contractors

REPORTS TO: Response Coordinators

RESPONSIBILITIES: Good housekeeping, reporting maintenance issues & incidents 



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



There are currently no planned changes to improve safety. Rather, the company believes that diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework that allows for the continued improvement to the level of safety at the Coalgate Tupelo Stonewall Gas Plant. Some of the key components of the program that will help maintain and, where applicable, improve safety are:



The Management of Change provisions ensure that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any change we make to chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.



The PHA provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual ev

aluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in our safety standards. 



The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous release thereby serving as an integral part of our safety program.



Internal and third party compliance audits will ensure that we maintain and increase our level of safety protection.
